sub_topic: Determining the girth of a graph.
message_1: Consider a simple graph G with 10 vertices and 13 edges. Determine the girth of G if one exists.
message_2:
The girth of a graph is the length of the shortest cycle in the graph. To determine the girth of G, we can use the following inequality:

girth(G) ≤ 2 * floor( (2 * |E|) / |V| )

where |E| is the number of edges and |V| is the number of vertices in the graph.

In this case, |E| = 13 and |V| = 10. Plugging these values into the inequality, we get:

girth(G) ≤ 2 * floor( (2 * 13) / 10 )
girth(G) ≤ 2 * floor( 26 / 10 )
girth(G) ≤ 2 * floor( 2.6 )
girth(G) ≤ 2 * 2
girth(G) ≤ 4

So, the girth of G is at most 4. Since the smallest possible cycle in a simple graph has a length of 3, the girth of G must be either 3 or 4 if a cycle exists.
